name: 吳和庭
objective: This course contains the basic theories in probability and random processes. It includes probability measures, random variables, the law of large number, statistical inference, random processes and stationary processes. This course offers substantial probabilistic and statistical backgrounds for the machine learning (ML) field and serves as a basic course in field of communications, networks and controls in graduate school.
schedule:
The course website is posed on course "1141_隨機信號與系統_350366" in the platform of 北科 i 學園 PLUS platform. Please check course link (https://istudy.ntut.edu.tw/learn/index.php) for course website.
Announcement, homework assignment and updated information will be posted on the course website.

Week 1. Reviews of Probability Concepts
Week 2. Discrete and Continuous Random Variables
Week 3. Sequential Events, Conditional Probability and Conditional Expectation
Week 4. Multiple Random Variables
Week 5. Functions of Random Variables
Week 6. Random Vectors
Week 7. Sums of Random Variables
Week 8. Moment Generating Functions, Central Limit Theorem
Week 9. Midterm; The Sample Mean
Week 10. Point Estimates of the Model Parameter
Week 11. Confidence Intervals; Significance Testing
Week 12. Binary and Multiple Hypothesis Testing
Week 13. Estimation of Random Variables
Week 14. Optimal Estimation; MAP and ML Estimation
Week 15. Definitions and Types of Random Processes
Week 16. The Poisson Process; The Brownian Process
Week 17. Stationary Random Processes
Week 18. Final Exam

materials:
Prerequisites: Probability, Transform Theory
Textbook:  Yates and Goodman, “Probability and Stochastic Processes,” 2nd Ed., John Wiley & Sons, 2005. (You may choose the 3rd ed. of this textbook, which contains similar contents and was published in 2015.)

References:
1.	Leon-Garcia, “Probability and Random Processes for Electrical Engineering,” 3rd ed., Pearson, 2009.
2.	Childers, “Probability and Random Processes”, Irwin, 1997.
3.	Papoulis and Pillai, “Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic Processes,” 4th ed., Mc-Graw-Hill, 2002.
4.	Stark and Woods, “Probability and Random Processes with application to Signal Processes”, 3rd ed., Prentice Hall, 2002.
5.	Ross, “Introduction to Probability Models”, 7th ed., Academic Press, 2000.
6.	Ghahramani, “Fundamentals of Probability with Stochastic Processes”, 3rd ed., Prentice Hall, 2005.
7.	Bhat and Miller, “Elements and Applied Stochastic Processes”, 3rd ed., 2002.
8.	Ross, “A First Course in Probability”, 7th ed., Prentice -Hall, 2006
